text:
Hi folks!

We are making a tool for external analysis of traffic to mobile apps. Specifically, to detect fraud traffic.
If you have traffic from networks or agencies, you can send me the id of the app and I will tell you if we can see the fraud.

It would be great to get deeper feedback about the system, so if you can share some time we can make it via:
1. 20-30 mins demo call
2. 1-week trial

DM me if you are willing to help or wish to check your app for fraud.

P.s. It's free :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
You're so welcome, Steph!

The initial survey is really short:

• List all websites/brands you're looking for help with
• Which services do you think you need? (I include an "I'm not sure" option)
• Which of these best describes your company/brand? (eComm, SBB, healthcare provider, influencer, news/media, or Other)
• What's your favorite place to buy coffee or tea? (We send a $20 gift card after discovery calls)
• How did you hear about us? (This usually gives me insight into what kind of company they are and what they know about us)
I'll provide pricing by service at any time before the discovery call if they ask, but I typically discuss it on the discovery call (typically near the end). Often, clients who ask via email before scheduling a call have a pretty exact budget in mind, so me giving them a price range helps to qualify or disqualify them (on their end). On the discovery call, I'll do a quick calculation of what I recommend and then quote it as a range, but I don't give the exact price until my follow-up email/proposal so that I make sure I'm only recommending what I think they truly need.

Once a client has signed a contract with us and paid their first invoice, I send over a more thorough survey to get a brief of everything we need to know about their audience, tone, perspectives, etc. Because we do some pretty particular healthcare topics, I've also had follow-up calls for ~30 minutes with a few clients to have them dictate out their medical perspectives/research they focus on for those topics.

I hope that helps!!

I hope that helps!!

text:
Hey <@U032J4JB40Z> - Way to go on getting started!

Buying a domain and buying hosting are 2 different things. And you need both to use WordPress (.org) You purchased the domain on Google, now you need to purchase hosting and then install WordPress on your hosting server.

For hosting, there are tons of options. I use SiteGround for <https://hannahwiginton.com|my own website> and Liquid Web for some bigger sites.

Your hosting will give you 2 nameserver addresses and you will enter these into your Google domains account. This will point your domain and website to the host.

Most hosts have a 1-click install for WordPress. From there, you install a theme.

Here's <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5mxi74KGnz8|how to point your domain to hosting> :movie_camera: (this tutorial demonstrates with SiteGround but the idea is the same with any hosting)

Here's a <https://www.wpcrafter.com/how-to-make-a-website-in-10-minutes/|helpful tutorial> and <https://www.wpcrafter.com/make-business-website-using-wordpress-elementor/|another one> for installing WordPress on your hosting and adding a theme

text: Agency perspective: We have recently started using a rate card as a qualifying tool -- essentially weeding out folks who aren't comfortable w/ our rates before we spend time on them. As far as format, it's literally just a two-column table w/ description on the left and price range on the right.

elements.text: Agency perspective: We have recently started using a rate card as a qualifying tool -- essentially weeding out folks who aren't comfortable w/ our rates before we spend time on them. As far as format, it's literally just a two-column table w/ description on the left and price range on the right.

text:
In my experience, having worked in both capacities:
• A content strategist is a leading hand strategy role. They create a content plan and coordinate with SEO, web teams, PR, sales, and other relevant teams to create content for different goals. They define which content types to create where and how to best support the customer journey from different perspectives. They define the goals of content and determine KPIs for individual pieces, and those all contribute to the overarching monthly and yearly goals (increase web traffic to x site by xx%, boost sign ups and applications by xx%, increase email list sign ups by xx%, etc). They also determine which actions are most likely to contribute to revenue-generation (like investing in support documentation for sales teams instead of a podcast to raise awareness, because the most pressing business problem is underperforming customer service or onboarding)
• A content marketer is more of a doer - I think more often than not, a lot of content marketing managers in practice are content marketers and not experienced strategists. They are creating the content or drilling down on what content their team will create to support the overarching strategy, goals, and KPIs. They could own a particular channel or relationship with a team (like a content lead that supports sales enablement, or a content marketer that focuses on a particular social channel. In many cases, content marketing managers have someone above or alongside them defining goals/don't have express experience demonstrating how content marketing supports revenue growth (IMO -- obviously not the case everywhere, but the bigger the org, the more often I've seen this dynamic).

elements.text: In my experience, having worked in both capacities:

A content strategist is a leading hand strategy role. They create a content plan and coordinate with SEO, web teams, PR, sales, and other relevant teams to create content for different goals. They define which content types to create where and how to best support the customer journey from different perspectives. They define the goals of content and determine KPIs for individual pieces, and those all contribute to the overarching monthly and yearly goals (increase web traffic to x site by xx%, boost sign ups and applications by xx%, increase email list sign ups by xx%, etc). They also determine which actions are most likely to contribute to revenue-generation (like investing in support documentation for sales teams instead of a podcast to raise awareness, because the most pressing business problem is underperforming customer service or onboarding)

A content marketer is more of a doer - I think more often than not, a lot of content marketing managers in practice are content marketers and not experienced strategists. They are creating the content or drilling down on what content their team will create to support the overarching strategy, goals, and KPIs. They could own a particular channel or relationship with a team (like a content lead that supports sales enablement, or a content marketer that focuses on a particular social channel. In many cases, content marketing managers have someone above or alongside them defining goals/don't have express experience demonstrating how content marketing supports revenue growth (IMO -- obviously not the case everywhere, but the bigger the org, the more often I've seen this dynamic).

text: <@U01NJ39M36K> - I'm also curious -- do you do a $2,000+ or something similar when listing starting rates? How does the conversation go when the scope is beyond that starting rate (which, I imagine, happens often)?

text: We title the piece "Sample Rate Card" (not that anyone reads that part :face_with_rolling_eyes: ), and include a range. The top end of the range is one we would be delighted to charge anyone. Eg, for complex white papers the top rate is something like $3/word.

elements.text: We title the piece "Sample Rate Card" (not that anyone reads that part
), and include a range. The top end of the range is one we would be delighted to charge anyone. Eg, for complex white papers the top rate is something like $3/word.

text:
Honestly, I let the potential client lead on this one. It is much easier and faster to hop on a Zoom call, share screens then and there, and hash out details.

But some clients prefer to do chat back and forth, others prefer to do an initial phone call. I am comfortable with whatever, but I do account for that time in my final quote, too.

My most preferred method is for them to fill out my contact form on my website because it triggers some automatic emails and questionnaires that covers a lot of details without us ever having to communicate directly from the get-go! (I use Workflows in Dubsado for this).

From there, I prefer emails/chat (like Slack or their preferred CRM) for touching base and follow up. Then, typically a final Zoom call to wrap everything up and see about continuing to work together (or not).

Hope that helps!

text: I use a rate card as a freelancer for the exact reason Michaela mentioned—it weeds out people who aren’t a good fit from a budgetary perspective. I keep mine in a Google sheet and update it ~6 months (because nobody’s going to give you a raise except yourself!). I’ll either copy/paste as a two-column table, also similar to what Michaela described, or just pull the relevant rows based on what the prospect has said they’re looking for. I always include a note about “these rates can vary depending on subject matter, research required, how outline development works, etc. but should give us an idea of whether I’d be a good fit for your budget”.

text: Here to double down on the "Notion's not for content creation/editing" train.  Our company heavily uses Notion, and we have always used Gdocs for content. Our product/engineering org tried to use Notion for content for their technical blog (which I help them manage), and I even convinced them to make the switch into Gdocs. I use Asana for project managing our marketing content calendar, and we use Notion to project manage the technical blog calendar. Different workflows for different types of teams.
